awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Faster and Better Algorithms for, and via, Mathematical Programming Relaxations
awd_abstract_narration:
Optimization algorithms underpin fundamental advances in computer science, engineering and social sciences. As an example, the spectacular success of machine learning in the recent past is partly due to the important role of a class of continuous-optimization algorithms. In another direction there have been a number of breakthrough advances on fundamental and widely applicable problems for graphs and networks, such as the maximum-flow and minimum-cut problems, based on fruitful interactions between continuous optimization and discrete optimization. Increasing data-set sizes and new models of computation require further advances in optimization algorithms to reap the rewards of the data revolution. This proposal aims to develop faster approximation algorithms for a class of continuous-optimization problems and to leverage these algorithms to obtain faster approximation algorithms for several well-studied and applicable problems in discrete and combinatorial optimization. The project will support and train one PhD student in the design and analysis of algorithms at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The investigator plans to write a survey on recent developments on fast approximation schemes for positive linear programming with an emphasis on applications to implicit programs that arise in combinatorial optimization. The investigator will continue to develop and teach a course on algorithms for big data at the University of Illinois and lecture notes and related material will be made publicly available.

The technical focus of the project is to develop fast approximation algorithms via mathematical-programming relaxations for a number of fundamental problems in discrete optimization. This involves developing fast algorithms for solving the relaxation as well as fast algorithms for rounding. The interplay between discrete and continuous methods will be an important technical viewpoint.  The project will have two thrusts.  The first is to develop fast algorithms for solving positive linear programs and several concrete applications. A particular focus will be on implicit linear programs that arise in combinatorial optimization. The second thrust will be fast algorithms for the traveling salesperson problem (TSP) and related problems in both undirected and directed graphs. Applications to submodular objective functions will also be considered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project developed faster exact and approximation algorithms for a number of problems in discrete and combinatorial optimization. The project resulted in more than ten publications and a PhD thesis.


1. A significant contribution of the project was to develop and analyze algorithms for the well-known densest subgraph problem and its generalizations. These problems arise in a number of applications in graph and network mining. The PI and collaborators showed that an iterative algorithm based on greedy peeling convergest o an optimum solution, answering a conjecture in the area. An important aspect of the work was to consider a general class ofdensity problems based on supermodularity. The work showed that iterative peeling converges for any problem in this general class and this implies a simple and efficient unified heuristic.  The project also developed new fast algorithms for densest subgraph problem based on maximum flow and convex optimization. The PI and collaborators developed faster dynamic algorithms for the densest subgraph problem and related graph orientation problems.


2. The project developed faster algorithms for several graph problems including rooted connectivity and bounded degree spanning tree via  combinatorial methods and mathematical programming based methods.


3. The project developed several new approximation algorithms for network design, and along the way resolved an open question on the integrality gap of an LP relaxation for non-uniform buy-at-bulk network design which was open for more than fifteen years.


4. The project developed new approximation algorithms for clustering with outliers motivated by fairness considerations.


5. The project developed new approximation algorithms for several problems involving submodular objectives with applications in covering, packing, prophet inequalities, and fair allocation.

6. The project developed a unified framework to speed up LP based algorithms in computation geometry via the multiplicative weight update method.

The project supported multiple PhD students. One of them finished their dissertation based on research for the grant. Another PhD student is on course to finish their dissertation this coming year. The PI has also advised and mentored several undergraduate students during the course of this grant. The PI continued to develop a course on algorithms for big data that has benefited students at the University of Illinois and beyond. Material from this course including slides and videos are publicly available, and these were used for courses offered at other institutions. The PI, and students supported by the grant, disseminated the results from the project via a number of talks and presentations at conferences, workshops, and at seminars.
